artworkDetails.author: Francesco Lojacono
artworkDetails.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Velit et iste ut odit recusandae accusantium vero, sit quis repudiandae ipsa laboriosam debitis mollitia rem veniam.

artworkDetails.title: The Starry Night
artworkDetails.author: Vincent van Gogh
artworkDetails.description: One of Vincent van Gogh's most famous works, painted during his stay at the Saint-Rémy-de-Provence asylum.

artworkDetails.title: Mona Lisa
artworkDetails.author: Leonardo da Vinci
artworkDetails.description: The Mona Lisa is one of the most famous paintings in the world, known for the mysterious smile of the woman depicted.

artworkDetails.title: The Kiss
artworkDetails.author: Gustav Klimt
artworkDetails.technique: Oil and gold leaf on canvas
artworkDetails.description: One of Klimt's most iconic works, characterized by the use of gold leaf and intricate decorative patterns.

artworkDetails.title: The Persistence of Memory
artworkDetails.author: Salvador Dalí
artworkDetails.description: A famous painting by Dalí depicting melting clocks, symbolizing the relativity of time and memory.

artworkDetails.title: The Raft of the Medusa
artworkDetails.author: Théodore Géricault
artworkDetails.description: A dramatic portrayal of a real event, the wreck of the frigate Medusa, which caused a scandal at the time.

artworkDetails.title: Night cafe in Arles
artworkDetails.author: Vincent van Gogh
artworkDetails.description: A painting showing a starry night over the Rhône River in Arles, with couples strolling along the riverbank.

artworkDetails.title: The Birth of Venus
artworkDetails.author: Sandro Botticelli
artworkDetails.description: A masterpiece of Italian Renaissance depicting the goddess Venus emerging from the sea on a shell.

artworkDetails.title: The Garden of Earthly Delights
artworkDetails.author: Hieronymus Bosch
artworkDetails.description: A complex triptych rich in symbolic details, representing heaven, earthly life, and hell.

artworkDetails.title: The Creation of Adam
artworkDetails.author: Michelangelo
artworkDetails.description: Part of the Sistine Chapel ceiling, depicting the moment God gives life to Adam.

artworkDetails.title: Light
artworkDetails.author: Lorenzo Oliva
artworkDetails.description: The painting depicts man's search for his own needs, for happiness, for love, represented precisely by that light, the protagonist of the work, which the characters reach out for, in pursuit, as if achieving this were a competition with others or, even, with themselves.

artworkDetails.title: The teather
artworkDetails.author: Lorenzo Oliva
artworkDetails.description: An individual is on a stage, the scene represents a “misunderstood” moment: this can be the culmination of a movement, of a show, or the beginning, the pose from which everything begins, but every “end” can and must not be anything other than a new beginning. The subject holds a mask in his hand: in this moment it can be approached and worn, just as it can be removed, to show one’s essence.

artworkDetails.title: The ineluctable essence of being
artworkDetails.author: Lorenzo Oliva
artworkDetails.description: The painting expresses disintegration of planes of existence. Its moral is based on the concept that every single human being has still significance, value and reason for life; starting from the expression “cogito ergo sum” (I think, therefore I am), the inner question of the artwork is: I am who I am, or I am who I think I am?
